Description: Rim and shoulder sherd of North Ionian black-figure pottery dinos; dull cream slip; interior: wide black painted band at top; on top of rim, black-figure hunting scene, facing inwards: to right, the head of the frieze, a deer to left, head turned back; to right two fully preserved ridden horse and the rump of a third; red on necks of animals and, roughly, on saddlecloths; white dors on bridles and deer's body. Edge of rim to top of shoulder glazed; billet pattern below; on shoulder frieze of dappled deer running to left, part of five preserved, with similar red and white additions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd joins Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.54.e.1899. The sherd also belongs to the same vase as Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.54.a.1899, GR.54.b.1899, GR.54.c.1899 and possibly belongs to the same vase as Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.54.f.1899 and Cairo JE46338. Cook suggests that this sherd belongs to an early and experimental phase of the Clazomenian black-figure style. E.R. Price (East Greek Pottery, 1927, 22) argued that white-slip Clazomenian pottery was the link between the Clazomenian sarcophagi, which were covered in a white slip, and the later Clazomenian black-figure wares. She explained that the features (the use of white dots as well as the use of white lines together with incised lines for inner details) on the white slip sherds are paralleled both on the sarcophagi and the later vases. Cook (1952 note 64) rejected that argument on the basis of both dating and styles.
